title: Evolution: The History of an Idea, Los Angeles: University of California Press. 64 Further Reading Two philosophical approaches to natural selection which are also historically sensitive are
Darwinism’s Struggle for Survival
Darwinism Evolving: Systems Dynamics and the Genealogy of Natural Selection

container-title: The Nature of Selection: Evolutionary Theory in Philosophical Focus
title: Two works that focus on natural selection primarily as it is understood in modern biology, but which cover far more than natural selection alone, are
Darwin’s Dangerous Idea: Evolution and the Meanings of Life
Nature’s Purposes: Analyses of Function and Design in Biology
Humans and Other Animals
Hull and Ghiselin defend the view that species are individuals in a number of places, including
A Radical Solution to the Species Problem’

note: and his view has been attacked by Mohan Matthen and Marc Ereshefsky:
title: A Matter of Individuality’
94 Further Reading Paul Griffiths has defended the view of species as kinds
Squaring the Circle: Natural Kinds with Historical Essences’
Taxonomy, Polymorphism and History: An Introduction to Population Structure Theory’

container-title: E. Mayr, Evolution and the Diversity of Life
note: reprinted in 1976), and Sober’s important reflections on the issue:
title: Griffiths’s paper also discusses the topic of ‘population thinking’, but readers should begin with Mayr’s original paper (first published in 1959
Typological versus Population Thinking’
Evolution, Population Thinking, and Essentialism’
For a recent examination, from a philosophical perspective, of Darwinism’s relationship to typological thinking, population thinking and essentialism see
The Changing Role of the Embryo in Evolutionary Thought

note: originally published in A. Fine and P. Machamer (eds) PSA Volume Two (1986): 3–13. Four Evidence
title: David Hull’s view of species as individuals has long made him suspicious of the concept of human nature. He makes his sceptical case in
On Human Nature’

title: Darwin’s Debt to Philosophy: An Examination of the Influence of the Philosophical Ideas of John F. W. Herschel and William Whewell on the Development of Charles Darwin’s Theory of Evolution’

title: The Structure and Strategy of Darwin’s “Long Argument”’

Darwin on Generation, Pangenesis and Sexual Selection’

Inference to the Best Explanation

title: The Design Argument’

Darwin and Victorian Christianity’

Darwin’s Cathedral: Evolution, Religion and the Nature of Society
Breaking the Spell: Religion as a Natural Phenomenon

Darwinian Concepts in the Philosophy of Mind’

container-title: What Emotions Really Are: The Problem of Psychological Categories
title: Paul Griffiths’s recent philosophical study of the emotions draws on a rich range of sources, and is also a good place to look for more detail on Ekman’s work
A review of work on the universality of emotion categories can be found in
Culture and the Categorization of Emotions’
On the apparent conflict between evolutionary views and those of social anthropology, Mallon and Stich’s article is useful
The Odd Couple: The Compatibility of Social Construction and Evolutionary Psychology’
Sense and Nonsense: Evolutionary Perspectives on Human Behaviour

Conjectures and Refutations
Conjectures and Refutations

Evolutionary Epistemology’
A useful collection of essays on memes – some hostile, some friendly – was published a few years ago
Darwinizing Culture
Daniel Dennett also discusses the meme concept in a balanced and characteristically lively fashion towards the end of his book on Darwinism
Darwin’s Dangerous Idea: Evolution and the Meanings of Life

Not by Genes Alone: How Culture Transformed Human Evolution

title: Evelleen Richards has written an impressive historical study of Darwin’s views on women
Darwin and the Descent of Women’
Political allegations of one kind or another were slung around with frequency during the sociobiology debate of the 1970s. There is a lively history of this debate
Defenders of the Truth
Peter Singer makes the case for the Left’s need to rethink some of its assumptions in a short and snappy book
A Darwinian Left: Politics, Evolution and Cooperation

Adapting Minds: Evolutionary Psychology and the Persistent Quest for Human Nature
